docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials last week issued model standards for the 300 fertility clinics in the nation, giving states a tool if they choose to start accrediting such clinics. State action is voluntary, but some state legislators have been considering establishing some regulatory framework, especially after incidents like the embryo mix-up at a New York laboratory in which one woman gave birth to twins, one of whom was another couple's genetic child.

headline.main: A New 'to-Do' List for Fertility Clinics

docs.abstract: Federal health officials issue model standards for 300 fertility clinics in nation, giving states a tool if they choose to start accrediting such clinics; guidelines, issued by Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala, are intended to make sure that embryology laboratories and clinics meet standards on laboratory procedures and equipment, record keeping and personnel qualifications (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Allowing a test-tube baby to mature just a bit more before implanting the embryo in the mother's womb may improve a couple's chances of having a baby, doctors reported today. The increasingly popular test-tube technique known as in vitro fertilization involves taking an egg from a woman and sperm from a man and fertilizing the egg in a laboratory dish instead in the body.

headline.main: Time Lends Hand to Test-Tube Fertilization

docs.abstract: Doctors, writing in Fertility and Sterility, journal of American Society for Reproductive Medicine, say that allowing test-tube baby to mature just a bit more before implanting embryo in mother's womb may improve a couple's chances of having baby (M)
docs.snippet: Allowing a test-tube baby to mature just a bit more before implanting the embryo in the mother's womb may improve a couple's chances of having a baby, doctors reported today.     The increasingly popular test-tube technique known as in vitro...

docs.lead_paragraph: Belly dancing has its place in dimly lit clubs, thick with incense and the beat of drums. But it is certainly not what you expect to find in an urban gym. In fact, though, you can. Both Equinox and New York Health and Racquet Club in New York have started belly dancing programs, tailoring the dance into a legitimate workout. In fact, said Judy Taylor, the director of public relations for Equinox Fitness Clubs, ''Any kind of ethnic dance is catching on nationally.'' It's a strange confluence, and one that ever-insatiable gym goers are responding to enthusiastically. Curious, I signed up, too.

headline.main: How to Build Abs of Undulating Steel

docs.abstract: Several health clubs in New York City start belly dancing programs, tailoring dance into legitimate workout; Amanda Hesser describes her experience at Equinox, noting how belly dancing workout increases coordination, endurance, balance and toning; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, some obstetricians said that April 9 was the prime date for couples hoping to conceive the first baby born on Jan. 1, 2000. Many people apparently took the advice to heart, encouraged by special deals from hotels, contests and, perhaps, the belief that a maternity ward is as good a place as any to spend the last New Year's Eve of the 1900's, since every other establishment of note has long since been booked.

headline.main: Year's First Baby? On Whose Watch?

docs.abstract: Comment on issues related to how to determine accuracy of claims about first baby born in year two thousand (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Masciarelli's guinea fowl are fighting Lyme disease on his front lawn. All day, birds nip at the turf, strut a bit, then bury their beaks again. The guinea fowl are ridding Mr. Masciarelli's Hudson Valley property of the ticks that carry Lyme disease by eating them. At least that is the idea.

headline.main: Guinea Fowl Peck Away At Lyme Disease Ticks

docs.abstract: Some people are employing guinea fowl to combat Lyme disease, by ridding their property of ticks that spread Lyme disease in verdant areas of Northeast and elsewhere; say that birds peck at the turf, seeking and devouring ticks; such endorsements have driven demand for guinea fowl beyond their traditional role as gourmet entree; new generation of guinea fowl chicks called keets is ready for market, and retailers report brisk business (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that companies that offer nutrition information and provide healthy food choices in their cafeterias significantly improve the dietary habits of their employees. In the study, which was a follow-up to the Working Well Trial, the largest workplace cancer and nutrition trial in the United States, researchers handed out questionnaires to more than 9,000 employees. Participants evaluated their smoking status, described their food habits and indicated their intentions of changing their eating and smoking habits.

headline.main: Cutting the Fat for Healthier Companies

docs.abstract: New study finds that companies that offer nutrition information and provide healthy food choices in their cafeterias significantly improve dietary habits of their employees (S)
docs.snippet: A new study has found that companies that offer nutrition information and provide healthy food choices in their cafeterias significantly improve the dietary habits of their employees.    In the study, which was a follow-up to the Working Well Trial,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Staff members in hospital intensive-care units sometimes joke that the best time to be a patient is during business hours. Otherwise, they say, doctors may be scarce. Whether that is true is unknown. But now a group of intensive care specialists from Johns Hopkins Hospital here is trying to make the question moot. The group has developed a remote surveillance system that is designed to allow specialists to monitor intensive care patients from long distance, 24 hours a day.

headline.main: Finding Value in Intensive Care, From Afar

docs.abstract: Group of intensive care specialists from Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore develops remote surveillance system that is designed to allow specialists to monitor intensive care paients from long distance, 24 hours a day; system, with video cameras and computers, will allow teams of doctors, nurses and technicians at a remote command center outside of hospital to observe up to 40 patients at a time and evaluate continuous flow of data from bedside, like heart rate and blood pressure; trial of system in Baltimore hospital cut mortality among intensive care patients by more than half (M)
docs.snippet: Staff members in hospital intensive-care units sometimes joke that the best time to be a patient is during business hours. Otherwise, they say, doctors may be scarce.    Whether that is true is unknown. But now a group of intensive care specialists...

docs.lead_paragraph: During a routine physical, a 75-year-old patient named Joseph was surprised to learn that his pulse was highly irregular: 50 beats one minute, 140 the next, seemingly without provocation. He was surprised because, he said, he felt fine and hadn't noticed any symptoms, except for three brief, isolated periods of complete lethargy that had occurred over three months. Diagnosis: atrial fibrillation, a chaotic rhythm in the heart's upper chambers that empty blood into the ventricles, the heart's main pumping chambers. When the atriums function erratically, they can disrupt the rhythm of the ventricles, causing the heart to race one minute and crawl the next. People with atrial fibrillation, or A.F., often experience palpitations, a strong, racing heart that typically beats 140 to 180 times a minute. Other symptoms like dizziness, faintness, shortness of breath and fatigue can result when the heart cannot pump enough blood to the body and brain.

headline.main: Often Overlooked, a Heart Disorder Puts Many at Great Risk

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on heart disorder known as atrial fibrillation, chaotic rhythm in heart's upper chambers that empty blood into the ventricles, heart's main pumping chambers; when atriums function erratically, they can disrupt rhythm of ventricles, causing heart to race one minute and crawl the next; experts say atrial fibrillation is often underappreciated and undertreated; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Memory lapses in older people may signal that a mailbox of memory is full rather than that the brain fails to process information, a new study on memory suggests. ''As we get older, we run out of places to store new information,'' said Dr. H. Lee Swanson, a psychologist at the University of California at Riverside and the author of the study. ''We have a limited amount of space in our memory system.''

headline.main: When The Brain's Mailbox Is Full

docs.abstract: New study on memory suggests that memory lapses in older people may signal that a mailbox of memory is full rather than that brain fails to process information; findings reviewed; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nadine McGann is thinking very hard, but she cannot remember the last time that she felt joy, or happiness, or even simple pleasure. On a good day, she drags herself out of bed after her sister's daily wake-up call, walks her dogs in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and slogs through the afternoon, fighting anxiety, inertia and fatigue. On a bad day, she mostly stays in bed. ''I don't really know what it is like to feel good,'' she says.

headline.main: Some Still Despair in a Prozac Nation

docs.abstract: Depression still afflicts many Americans, even in an age of Prozac; depression, a recurrent illness that afflicts more than 19 million Americans over age of 18, in some cases is considerably more difficult to treat than drug advertisements suggest; psychiatrists estimate that 60 to 70 percent of people who can tolerate side effects of antidepressants get better with first drug they take; but 10 percent do not respond--even after trials on many different drugs; and still others--estimates of how many vary--get better but do not recover completely; case of Nadine McGann, who suffers from extreme depression, discussed; photo; other examples cited (M)
